Blaming labor costs and inflation, the Administration announced Wednesday an effective rent increase of at least fifteen percent
for all University housing.
Mr. Marvin Kaberle, of the

the Student Affairs Committee
that the residents of the Undergraduate Dormitories would suffer a fifteen percent raise in rent,

The increase is designed to counteract a 19.4 percent rise in University expenses projected for the
next fiscal year.
The increase in rents for the
Graduate facilities can be, kept

switchboards were continued, the
total rise in rent would be $96,200.

increase the freshman class next
year." He termed the 15% rent

Late News: Late Thursday afternoon, parties representing Laborers' International Union Local 1231, Nursing and
Hospital Employees Union Local 1199E, and Hopkins signed a
consent election agreement. The agreement sets the date for a
union representation election on Friday, April 3. The bargaining unit--those workers eligible to vote-includes nonprofessional
employees at the Homewood and East Baltimore campuses of
the University.

By TED ROHRLICH
Representatives from local unions 1231 and 1199 met
with Hopkins Vice President for Administration Robert
Kerley yesterday afternoon to formalize a consent agreement and set a date for a union representation election
for Hopkins non-professional employees.
The meeting came four months after the original election date of December 5, andontheheels of employee pay
hikes and a worker petition urging a meeting of all parties
involved to clear up confusion stemming from "vague and
con4ad1ctory statements from both of the unions and the
administrators of Hopkins."
Lawyers for 1199E got a court injunction to postpone
the original election indefinitely after repeated unsuccessful attempts to get on the Hopkins ballot.

No Election Until...

that there could be no election until 1231 and the University agreed to put 1199E on the ballot or the National Labor
Relations Board acted on a separate 1199 petition for
certification as. a representative of the Hopkins bargaining unit. Such a move would have the practical effect of

assuring 1199's presence on the ballot.
Three weeks ago, 1199E withdrew its NLRB petition,
and 1231 began negotiations with the University in secret.
At the same time, the University announced a pay boost
for its employees to bring wages here into line With those
at Hopkins Hospital. Workers at the Hospital are represented by Local 1199.

have been reached calling for a "three-box" ballot. Workers will have a choice of voting for 1199, 1231 or no union,

'Chester Wickwire is for Real—So Much Soul'
By HARVEY LUKSENBURG
During his seventeen years at Hopkins,
Dr. Chester Wickwire, Chaplain of the
University, has played a dominant role
In the struggle for civil rights in the city,
the state, perhaps the country.
He has run the gauntlet which all fervent advocates of unpopular cases face:
aspiration, defeat, arrest, work, partial
victory.
To the majority of Hopkins students,
he is a figure. To the leaders of Baltimore's black community, he is a major
figure.
Dr. Wickwire's career at Hopkins began in 1953. He soon engaged himself
in the various demonstations that were
then starting to crack Baltimore's hitherto placid racial status quo. In the late
fifties he participated in an attempt to
integrate the Northwood Theatre, near
Morgan State College. He also aided in
efforts to desegregate facilities at Ocean
City, Maryland.

Grooving on a Worm
As the News-Letter Old Staff rides slowly into the sunset and the
News-Letter New Staff breaks from the starting gate, only the gnarled
figure of the Lone Ranger disturbs the monotony of the landscape.
"Where is Tonto?" the fans ask. "I don't know," the Lone Ranger replies.
"He was here a minute ago, but now I just don't know."
Tonto's a part-time Indian, but can he be really blamed? Others are
part-time students in part-time Universities. The rest wait for part-time
politicians to do something with their part-time cities and countries. Even
the sun shines only when it is clear outside. All of us dream of the big-time.
"All I want is a vote. That is all that I ask," they cry. All right, we'll
a vote—just fill in this handy, e-z-read form: are you tall enough?
you
give
are you strong enough? smart enough? conscientious, hardworking, happy,
secure, mature, hairy, virile enough? Are you man enough? Also, are you
now or have you ever been a member of any group? "All I want is a vote.
Just a small say."
The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory puts out
a little newspaper whose front page story last week waxed indignant over
the nation's vile treatment of the Military-Industrial Complex. If people
would only get to meet them, it said, they would find what a nice group
they really are. The Lone Ranger isn't fooled. "Sleeping with a gun and
wearing a mask gets to be quite a bore," he says. "Plus I just heard that
Spiro is going to introduce a new bill changing everyone's birthday to
September 14, for consistency." The silent majority methodically applauds. "I got nothing to fear," the Lone Ranger smiles, "I was untimely
ripped."
The 1970's are here—the first decade without a single hero. Even Dr.
Coleman only made the bottom of the front page of the Times. The 'kid
from back home' is the king—on the battlefield, in the Senate, on the
streets, in the back-room heroin factory. Dr. Gordon's hero is Hubert
Humphrey. The Lone Ranger's hero is a young Goucher girl who says
only, "I don't know. I just don't know."
The I-don't-know syndrome is all-encompassing. It pervades all our
aspects, invades all our citadels, degrades all our lives. The Student
Council does not know what the answer to the Governance dilemma is. Dr.
Gordon does not know where we will get the money for a Student Union
building. Mr. Nixon does not know his secret time table to end the war.
Time Magazine hails the youth of today as the nation's saviors. "This is
the generation that seeks, but does not know."
The eminent physicist Heisenberg has a standard answer for the Idon't-know syndrome. He nods at the blackboard, looks for a piece of
chalk, sits back and says, "I don't care." He does care, however, for he
always carries around a blackboard without chalk. The News-Letter also
cares. We send a reporter over to him every day, hoping that he will say
something different.
Rumor has it that John Guess and Mark LaMar have a secret plan to
destroy the News-Letter and to build a motel where the Gatehouse now
stands. Readers, take a stand! Send your tax-free dollars to the powersucker of your choice!
Then, again, should the reader bother to get involved? Should he
even try to play a role in the mammoth power struggles he sees and feels
around him? Should he not save his money for taxes and rest easy in the
knowledge that he bows down to no one, salutes no one, cares about no
one? Readers, take a stand! Refuse to do anything!
But, all indications to the contrary, Spring will come, and, once we
pass the hurdle of a Saint-less Saint Patrick's Day, our expert horizonwatchers see no more trouble brewing. The Governance issue will be
solved, the bookstore will make piles of money, some department will
hire a black professor, all the Freshmen will voluntarily go to gym, a dying
alumnus will leave the University a billion dollars, all the rats will leave
Calvert Street for the suburbs, and the War will end in Vietnam.
The Lone Ranger has only one question. He keeps asking us, "Is it
'Better Red than Dead' or vice veisa?"

swimmer's trip to Oakland University in Michigan for the College
Division NCAA Swimming Championships which are being held Thursday through Saturday of this coming week.
In so doing, Wolk went out on a limb for which he deserves only
praise and commendation. His intention is to have the other three
classes reimburse the juniors with $100 each in order to even out the
distribution of the donation among all four classes. Although there is
no responsibility for the other classes' officers to back Wolk up,
we strongly recommend that they do simply to present a united front
to the Administration. The University has been delinquent in assuming its responsibility for paying the swimmers' way to the
NCAA's.
After having strained and sacrificed for an entire season, the swimmers are put upon by the administration to sacrifice an extra day of
classes in order to make the trip by car rather than by plane. Who do
we thank up there in the administration for this imposition on an athlete as a conscientious student?
Perhaps, and maybe rightfully so, the blame can stop with Director
of Student Affairs, Robert Bilgrave, who has remained mysteriously
quiet throughout the swimming team's crisis. Last year Bilgrave's
office gave $200 towards the swimmers' trip to Springfield, Mass,
for the NCAA's. This year he can only afford in the vicinity of $50.
This is but one of many examples where our penny-wise and poundfoolish Administration is forcing the students to fend for themselves.
Larry Wolk's laudable action proves that the students really do care.
Perhaps, our past cynicism has been created by an unresponsive
Administration.
Indications come from David Kaufman's Office that there will not
be need to repeat the swimmers'search for money to go to the NCAA's
next year. It is still not too late for those Administrators to donate
the extra money for the swimmers to fly. How about it? We've done
more than our share in meeting them halfway.
Athletes do more than just represent Hopkins undergraduates-they represent the entire university. It is high time that our administrators do more than just represent their own rung on "Lincoln's
ladder." Some already do "stand up to be counted," to borrow Coach
Sotir's phrase.
Now, not next year, is the time to show the undergraduates that
sense of caring for OUR HOPKINS is not just hollow words within
our hallowed walls. There need not and should not be a discrepancy
between student and administration concern.
Swimmers are providing the cars and drivers to make the trip to
Michigan. Swimmers spent literally over 100 hours lifeguarding at the

Grooving on a Worm
As the News-Letter Old Staff rides slowly into the sunset and the
News-Letter New Staff breaks from the starting gate, only the gnarled
figure of the Lone Ranger disturbs the monotony of the landscape.
"Where is Tonto?" the fans ask. "I don't know," the Lone Ranger replies.
"He was here a minute ago, but now I just don't know."
Tonto's a part-time Indian, but can he be really blamed? Others are
part-time students in part-time Universities. The rest wait for part-time
politicians to do something with their part-time cities and countries. Even
the sun shines only when it is clear outside. All of us dream of the big-time.
"All I want is a vote. That is all that I ask," they cry. All right, we'll
a vote—just fill in this handy, e-z-read form: are you tall enough?
you
give
are you strong enough? smart enough? conscientious, hardworking, happy,
secure, mature, hairy, virile enough? Are you man enough? Also, are you
now or have you ever been a member of any group? "All I want is a vote.
Just a small say."
The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory puts out
a little newspaper whose front page story last week waxed indignant over
the nation's vile treatment of the Military-Industrial Complex. If people
would only get to meet them, it said, they would find what a nice group
they really are. The Lone Ranger isn't fooled. "Sleeping with a gun and
wearing a mask gets to be quite a bore," he says. "Plus I just heard that
Spiro is going to introduce a new bill changing everyone's birthday to
September 14, for consistency." The silent majority methodically applauds. "I got nothing to fear," the Lone Ranger smiles, "I was untimely
ripped."
The 1970's are here—the first decade without a single hero. Even Dr.
Coleman only made the bottom of the front page of the Times. The 'kid
from back home' is the king—on the battlefield, in the Senate, on the
streets, in the back-room heroin factory. Dr. Gordon's hero is Hubert
Humphrey. The Lone Ranger's hero is a young Goucher girl who says
only, "I don't know. I just don't know."
The I-don't-know syndrome is all-encompassing. It pervades all our
aspects, invades all our citadels, degrades all our lives. The Student
Council does not know what the answer to the Governance dilemma is. Dr.
Gordon does not know where we will get the money for a Student Union
building. Mr. Nixon does not know his secret time table to end the war.
Time Magazine hails the youth of today as the nation's saviors. "This is
the generation that seeks, but does not know."
The eminent physicist Heisenberg has a standard answer for the Idon't-know syndrome. He nods at the blackboard, looks for a piece of
chalk, sits back and says, "I don't care." He does care, however, for he
always carries around a blackboard without chalk. The News-Letter also
cares. We send a reporter over to him every day, hoping that he will say
something different.
Rumor has it that John Guess and Mark LaMar have a secret plan to
destroy the News-Letter and to build a motel where the Gatehouse now
stands. Readers, take a stand! Send your tax-free dollars to the powersucker of your choice!
Then, again, should the reader bother to get involved? Should he
even try to play a role in the mammoth power struggles he sees and feels
around him? Should he not save his money for taxes and rest easy in the
knowledge that he bows down to no one, salutes no one, cares about no
one? Readers, take a stand! Refuse to do anything!
But, all indications to the contrary, Spring will come, and, once we
pass the hurdle of a Saint-less Saint Patrick's Day, our expert horizonwatchers see no more trouble brewing. The Governance issue will be
solved, the bookstore will make piles of money, some department will
hire a black professor, all the Freshmen will voluntarily go to gym, a dying
alumnus will leave the University a billion dollars, all the rats will leave
Calvert Street for the suburbs, and the War will end in Vietnam.
The Lone Ranger has only one question. He keeps asking us, "Is it
'Better Red than Dead' or vice veisa?"

By GEORGE KIRSCHBAUM
Sports Editor
After reading last Tuesday's "Jay's Nest", Larry Wolk, Juniorclass Secretary-treasurer, walked into Frank Comfort's office with the
commitment from his class to donate the $400 needed to finance the
swimmer's trip to Oakland University in Michigan for the College
Division NCAA Swimming Championships which are being held Thursday through Saturday of this coming week.
In so doing, Wolk went out on a limb for which he deserves only
praise and commendation. His intention is to have the other three
classes reimburse the juniors with $100 each in order to even out the
distribution of the donation among all four classes. Although there is
no responsibility for the other classes' officers to back Wolk up,
we strongly recommend that they do simply to present a united front
to the Administration. The University has been delinquent in assuming its responsibility for paying the swimmers' way to the
NCAA's.
After having strained and sacrificed for an entire season, the swimmers are put upon by the administration to sacrifice an extra day of
classes in order to make the trip by car rather than by plane. Who do
we thank up there in the administration for this imposition on an athlete as a conscientious student?
Perhaps, and maybe rightfully so, the blame can stop with Director
of Student Affairs, Robert Bilgrave, who has remained mysteriously
quiet throughout the swimming team's crisis. Last year Bilgrave's
office gave $200 towards the swimmers' trip to Springfield, Mass,
for the NCAA's. This year he can only afford in the vicinity of $50.
This is but one of many examples where our penny-wise and poundfoolish Administration is forcing the students to fend for themselves.
Larry Wolk's laudable action proves that the students really do care.
Perhaps, our past cynicism has been created by an unresponsive
Administration.
Indications come from David Kaufman's Office that there will not
be need to repeat the swimmers'search for money to go to the NCAA's
next year. It is still not too late for those Administrators to donate
the extra money for the swimmers to fly. How about it? We've done
more than our share in meeting them halfway.
Athletes do more than just represent Hopkins undergraduates-they represent the entire university. It is high time that our administrators do more than just represent their own rung on "Lincoln's
ladder." Some already do "stand up to be counted," to borrow Coach
Sotir's phrase.
Now, not next year, is the time to show the undergraduates that
sense of caring for OUR HOPKINS is not just hollow words within
our hallowed walls. There need not and should not be a discrepancy
between student and administration concern.
Swimmers are providing the cars and drivers to make the trip to
Michigan. Swimmers spent literally over 100 hours lifeguarding at the
pool to raise money to go to the NCAA's. Students raised 98.4% of.
the money to finance the trip. Nowhere does one see the word administration. As my parting shot, I ask, "How come?"
